data.text: Contents
Introduction
This policy identifies the management of the operating theatres at Mid Essex Hospital Trust (MEHT), which will
Optimise the use of theatre capacity
Maximise theatre performance
Minimise cancelled operations and
Improve services for the Trust's patients and staff.
All staff involved will be trained to a standard level, tailored to the individual's responsibilities. Each year all staff will undertake mandatory training.
All new Staff will be made aware of this policy and will form part of the induction with the theatre department. Failure to comply with Trust policy may lead to disciplinary action.
Purpose of the Theatre Access Policy
The purpose of this policy is to
Enable the efficient utilisation of theatres to meet delivery of Surgical Directorate capacity plans and the Trusts overall Access Policy,
To provide guidance for all theatre service Users; Clinicians, Trust Managers and Directorate Staff in the efficient, effective operation of theatres,
To set out the following agreed procedures for Elective, Urgent and Emergency Surgery including:
Theatre template scheduling and resource assignments,
Alterations to template schedules,
Patient booking and list organisation,
Pre-operative Anaesthetic Assessment (PAA).
The Scope of the Theatre Access Policy
This Policy applies to:
All Trust Staff who work in the Theatre Department,
All contracted/agency staff who provide patient services in theatres,
All staff with Honorary Contracts to enable them to undertake surgical; procedures in theatres,
All administrative staff who book patients onto theatre lists,
All surgical service managers,
All Associate Directors of Operations for surgical specialities

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) Trust Board
The Trust Board has the overall accountability and responsibility for ensuring ratified Trust Policies are adhered to by all staff who provide patient care in Mid Essex Hospital Trust.
The Elective Care Board
The Elective Care Board has the responsibility of monitoring and ensuring all elective care is delivered in a safe, effective and responsive manner to patients.
The Emergency Care Board
The Emergency Care Board has the responsibility of monitoring and ensuring all emergency care is delivered in a safe, effective and responsive manner to patients.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust Managing Director and Chief Operating Officer

The Managing Director is the Accountable Officer of the Trust and as such has overall accountability and responsibility for ensuring safe and effective systems are in place for patient care in the theatre environment and that staff are fully informed and skilled to carry out their responsibilities.

The chief operating officer is responsible for ensuring that there is a process for Scheduling the appropriate patients onto the correct lists and that patients receive their surgical intervention in a safe and timely manner.
Director of Nursing
The Director of Nursing has overall executive responsibility for ensuring effective systems are in place for safe patient care in a theatre setting.
Consultant Surgeons/Anaesthetists

The Consultant has overall responsibility to ensure surgical care in a theatre setting is provided at the appropriate time of day or night depending on the urgency of the patient with the appropriately skilled theatre team to assist with the surgical intervention.
Service Manager for Anaesthetics, Theatres and Critical Care

The Service Manager has the overall responsibility to ensure theatres are staffed with the appropriate skilled nursing and ODA staff and that systems and processes are in place to ensure theatre lists are safe and effectively delivered.
Theatre Matrons
Theatre Matrons have the overall responsibility of managing the day to day running of theatres to ensure patient care is delivered safely and in a timely manner by clinical teams.
Surgical Service Managers
Surgical Service Managers have the overall responsibility to ensure that elective lists are booked appropriately by administrative teams so that lists run effectively and are efficiently utilised.
Overview of Theatre Templates
Theatre sessions will be planned on the basis of the Activity & Capacity Schedule for the business year (April 1st to March st) by the Service Manager for

Anaesthetics, Theatres and Critical Care and the Assistant Director of Operations.  Theatre sessions are allocated based on each surgical directorate's projected planned sessional requirement identified in the annual business planning process. Allocated theatre sessions will include day case, elective and emergency sessions. 6.3  Each surgical speciality requirement for theatre sessions will be completed by January prior to the commencement of the business year, and will be reviewed,
approved and signed off by the Service Manager for Anaesthetics Theatres and Critical Care and ADO for CSSD.
The approved theatre plan will be presented in the form of the Master Theatre Template.

Any changes required by specialities which are over and above the previous year's allocation must be fully funded via the Trust's Business Case process no less than 3 months before the commencement of the new calendar year to allow for a 3 month lead in time for recruitment of staff and theatre instruments procurement.

The Business Case must include funding for theatre sessional staff, recovery staff, Radiographer (if required), day unit staff, admissions ward, anaesthetic medical staff and the appropriate level of administrative support. In addition resource must be  funded  for  Sterile  Services including instruments.  In  addition  to  workforce allocation the appropriate funding must be identified for non-pay i.e. consumables, prosthetics, etc.

Theatre templates will not be changed until the Business Case has been fully funded by the Trust. Senior theatre managers will assist the speciality in the production of the business case to ensure the correct level of funding is provided.

The above process will also be followed during the financial year by specialities who wish to increase the level of capacity/sessions on a continual basis, i.e. if they recruit additional consultants who will undertake new or additional activity.
Master Template

The theatre template provides a visual spreadsheet of the theatre capacity and the demand requirement of the surgical specialties. No changes can be made to the master template without the approval of the Service Manager for Anaesthetics Theatres and Critical Care/Deputy, the ADO for CSSD.

Requests for permanent changes to the Master Template (e.g. a new consultant, or change of session days for a consultant) will be forwarded to the Service Manager for Anaesthetic Theatres and Critical Care/Deputy Clinical Director of Theatres & Anaesthetics. Please refer to section  for funding process.

If section  has been adhered to the Service Manager for Anaesthetics, Theatres and Critical Care will confirm availability of theatre sessions and will provide a start date for changes to take place in consultation with all stakeholders. If a session has been dropped and re assigned by a speciality and this is cost neutral to theatres this change can take place almost immediately and the Service Manager for Anaesthetics Theatres and Critical Care will confirm the start date to the speciality service manager.

The weekly theatre template is based on the agreed funded master theatre template and shows the specialities. Scheduling to the template will be based on the 6-4-2 system depicted in appendix 1 of this document.
The 6-4-2 process will be applied at the Theatre User Group (TUG) meeting on a weekly basis.
To ensure this system is robust all specialities must adhere to the Trust's 6 week leave policy without exception.
The Weekly Theatre Template
This is a prospective theatres' planning document that provides all stakeholders with a forward look of the theatre sessional plan.
Adding an Extra Session(s)

9.1. Any extra session above the agreed Master Theatre Template requires the grip and control process to be adhered before any additional sessions are arranged by the Service Manager for Anaesthetics Theatres and Critical Care. The Grip and Control process can be viewed in Appendix 3 of this policy. The speciality must commit to fully fund the session which may include bank/agency rates and additional consultant session rates.

9.2. Upon confirmation by the Service Manager for Anaesthetics, Theatres and Critical Care/Deputy that  the  additional  session has  been  sanctioned  via  the  grip  and control process the theatre data manager will:-
Formally request all theatre/anaesthetic managers to staff the session(s)
Clarify with all managers that the session is fully staffed
Inform the Specialty Manager of the Surgical Service or designee that
the session is staffed and will go ahead as per request,
Alter the weekly theatre template to reflect the change(s)
Communicate with all concerned stakeholders about the template
change ideally  working days in advance of the proposed surgery date.
Although every effort will be made, it may not be possible to facilitate an extra list at short notice.
Reinstating a Session
If a list reinstatement incurs an additional cost due to the necessity to use bank or agency staff to support the session this must be funded by the requesting speciality. See section 8.1.
Although every effort will be made, it may not be possible to re instate a list at short notice.
Patient Booking and List Organisation
Only patients that have been pre assessed as fit for surgery should be booked onto a theatre list.

Elective patient who DNA their pre assessment appointment will be discharged back to their G.P., unless they are on a cancer pathway or there are safeguarding issues, and will not be offered an alternative pre assessment appointment

Patients deemed fit for surgery will be assigned to the theatre session lists through a central scheduling system. List Scheduling will be in accordance with the theatre session duration. This expertise will be provided by a clinical member of staff working in the central theatre scheduling office and will be based on the procedure time sourced from Theatre Man.
Patients with a  day maximum wait for surgical intervention will have their operation scheduled within the designated period using the same process as stated above.

It is recognized that certain specialties have a patient population with a greater percentage of urgent cases. In agreement with the surgeons involved, a percentage of their list will remain unfilled until an agreed date closer to the actual date of surgery, and then if necessary will be filled with patients willing to come in for their surgery at short notice. This will also be reflected in flexibility within the pre assessment system for urgent patients.

For these urgent cases the theatre list will be published at least 5 working days ahead of the day of surgery so that final agreement regarding list order and confirmation of resources can be undertaken.

It is the Theatre Matrons and Senior Sister's responsibility to ensure the requisite equipment, instruments, and prosthesis are available for use according to the scheduled theatre list. The Theatre Matron will inform the surgeon at the earliest possible time if required items are not available for use, so that a decision to cancel, alter the procedure, or delay the patient's procedure can be made in a timely manner, and thus eliminate the need to cancel patients on the day of surgery.
If the patient requires an ITU or HDU bed post operatively it is the responsibility of the speciality to ‘book ‘the bed with the Critical Care Matron.
The speciality will inform the Service Manager for Anaesthetics Theatres and Critical Care/deputy of the need for an ITU/HDU post operatively at the TUG meeting.

The need for an ITU/HDU bed will also be reviewed at the TUG meetings to ensure no more than 2 elective patients per weekday requiring this level of care should be booked due to the risk of on the day cancellations. The TUG chair will have the authority to request a rescheduling of operation date if there are more than 2 patients requiring ITU/HDU on the same day.

To prevent delays in commencing the list on the day of surgery (if the ITU/HDU bed is not available) as the Intensivist have not completed their ward round to identify potential discharges, the speciality should book a short list filler on the same list who should always be the first patient on the list. This will ensure the list is being used while confirmation is being sought regarding ITU/HDU capacity.
Session Times

Start time: The theatre start time is the start of the first anaesthetic intervention, therefore all staff including surgeons and anaesthetist must have completed a team brief and be ready to start the list.
Finish times: The finish time of the session is indicated by the time the patient leaves the operating theatre for post anesthetic care unit or ICU.
This chart outlines the session timings;
Pre-Operative Anaesthetic Assessment

The  Trust  has  endorsed  the  principle  of  nurse  led  pre-operative  anaesthetic assessment supported by anaesthetic consultant input. Undertaking Pre-operative anaesthetic assessment ensures that patients are fit for their surgery.
Patients deemed not to be fit should be re-referred appropriately as a priority. Links with relevant medical specialities, e.g., (Cardiology and Respiratory medicine) will facilitate this process.

In some cases the anaesthetist may wish to refer the patient back to their G.P. for management i.e. high blood pressure etc. In this instance the Pre Assessment Nurse must contact the speciality manager and inform him/her of the outcome of the assessment. The speciality manager will ensure the surgeon discharges the patient and removes them from the waiting list in adherence with the Patient Access Policy.

Where as a consequence of anaesthetic pre assessment the patient will require ITU or HDU bed post operatively. Pre Assessment will meet weekly with the ITU lead, and book the appropriate level of bed at if feasible 2 weeks before the operation date to book a bed for the elective admission.
Procedure for Emergency and Trauma Cases NCEPOD  &
(Refer to Emergency Theatre Operational Policy; register number 14009)
Emergency cases between the hours of 00:01 hours to 08:00 hours will be life, limb saving surgery only.
Day of Surgery
The Theatre team will send for the first patient on the list promptly to ensure that the theatre start time is adhered to.
It is the responsibility of the Ward Sister and the surgical team to have patients who are first on the list, prepared and ready to come to theatre for 08.00 for the daily safety brief.

The lead of each theatre will attend the daily departmental safety huddle at 8am. The huddle is led by the band 7 who acts as the theatre coordinator for the day. The Safety huddle discusses incidents that have occurred and acts as a handover for other safety related issues.
The theatre teams will do their own safety huddle following the departmental safety huddle. So the information can be cascaded to the teams prior to the team brief.

The theatre teams will perform the World Health Organisation (WHO) checklist according to the WHO Safety Check List Policy which can be reviewed on the Trust Intranet. This Policy complies with The World Health Organisation (WHO) Safer Surgery Checklist.
Turnaround Time
The definition for theatre turnaround is the time that a patient exits from theatre room until a next patient enters the anaesthetic room and/or theatre room.

To ensure turn-around times between cases are met, it is the responsibility of the theatre sister or designee to ensure housekeeping/ Healthcare Support Workers are available to assist in the clearing up towards the end of each case and to prepare for the next case.
Overruns

Predicted planned session overruns will be requested by the Clinical Director or Consultant Surgeon for the surgical session no less than  working days in advance once the theatre list is finalised, (see 6-4-2 process appendix 1). This request will follow the same process as the ‘extra list request'.

On the day of surgery if a session looks like it will overrun and will cause either a delayed start to the afternoon session, or a prolonged overrun at the end of the day, it is the responsibility of the theatre manager or designee to assess this situation in collaboration with the Floor anaesthetist and surgeon, who will look at all potential alternatives. Every effort will be taken to prevent patients being cancelled on the day of surgery. Appendix 4 shows the process that must be followed if there is a risk of cancelling patients on the day of their surgery for clinical and non-clinical reasons.

If no alternatives can the found to accommodate remaining patient(s) on the list, the Service Manager for Anaesthetics Theatres and Critical Care/deputy will inform the Surgeon and the ADO responsible for the for the surgical service and the patient(s) may be cancelled. The Ward Sister will only be informed the patient of the cancellation when everything possible has been done to prevent the patient cancellation see appendix 4. The Service Manager for Anaesthetics Theatres and Critical Care/Deputy will ask the speciality to provide a new TCI date to the patient before he/she is discharged.
Post Anaesthesia Care Unit (Recovery)

The anaesthetics and theatre directorate commit to providing specialist recovery skills to recover all patients immediately post-surgery/anaesthesia. To ensure consistency of care, and quality outcomes, specialised Recovery staff will be available to meet the demands for a 24/7 service.
A Post-Operative Anaesthetic discharge criteria score will be undertaken before the patient is discharged from the unit. Patients may be discharged home if appropriate

and will return to the Theatre Admissions Surgical Unit or Day Surgery to change into their outer garments and return home. Any medication prescribed by medical teams will be collected by the patient from these departments.

If the patient requires an inpatient stay, the ward will be contacted by the recovery team and a nurse will be dispatched to collect the patient. It is imperative to ensure the recovery staff are able to care for post-operative patients who have not been discharged and therefore the wards must respond as soon as possible to collect their patient/s.
If the patient requires an unexpected inpatient stay the theatre bed coordinator must to be contact by the recovery staff. Who in turn will contact the wards and bed management to source a bed.

The  recovery  unit  is  staffed  with  recovery  staff  on  Monday,  Tuesday  and Wednesday night as a full night shift to provide overnight services. All other nights of the week are covered as part of an on-call rota to provide overnight services for emergency cover.
Training Requirements

All theatre staff involved with patient services in theatres, clinical or non clinical will have the appropriate level of training for the role they provide. Therefore there will be no additional training required to ensure staff adhere to this policy.

Appendix 3: Cancellations on the Day of Surgery - Guidance

The definition of on the day cancellations mean cancellations on the day the patient was due to arrive, after the patient has arrived in hospital and or on the day of the operation. This does include patients who have not actually yet arrived in hospital and have been contacted prior to their arrival.

All potential cancellation should be escalated through the theatre matrons, service managers and the Assistant directors of operations before a final decision is made and the ward and the patient is notified to prevent avoidable on the day cancellations.
An operation which is cancelled but carried out with 24 hours, without the patient being discharged, should be documented as a postponement and not a cancellation.

This document is intended to provide guidance and clarity for on the day cancellations. Within this document there will be flow charts that will have to be followed to ensure that the correct process for cancelation is followed.
The on the day cancellations are divided into 2 groups:
Clinical reasons
Non- clinical reasons

The decision to cancel a patient on the day for clinical reason can only be done at consultant level. This can either be the consultant or senior surgeon and/or the consultant or senior anaesthetist. The objective is to offer a new procedure date at the time of cancellation where possible.
Examples of reasons for these non-clinical cancellations are: list overrun, lack of beds (ward/critical care), equipment unavailable, staff unavailability etc.
As soon as it becomes clear that an elective operation is to be cancelled due to non- clinical reasons the following people should be contacted at the earliest opportunity:
Senior member of the theatre team,
Theatre Matron
Service manager
Associate Director of Operations

This is to ensure that all options to prevent the cancellation the operation can be explored. Only if all options have been explored the Chief Operating Officer, or his or her deputy, will need to be informed. In the case of operation being cancelled by the Trust for non-clinical reasons on the day of admission, after admission or on the day of surgery the patient must be offered an admission date that is within 28 days of the cancellation in order to meet the criteria of the NHS guidelines for cancelled operations.
The cancelation data is to be discussed on a weekly basis per speciality with the Theatre Review Group.
Patients cancelled for clinical reasons
The decision to cancel patients for clinical reasons can ONLY be made by the consultant or senior surgeon and/or the consultant or senior anaesthetist.
